completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE REHNQUIST
completeLines.speech: We'll hear argument next in No. 00-957, Kansas v. Michael Crane. General Stovall.

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: Mr. Chief Justice, thank you, and may it please the Court: The Kansas Supreme Court has erroneously read this Court's decision in Kansas v. Hendricks as requiring a showing that a potentially sexually violent predator cannot control his behavior and that such a requirement has supplemented the two requisites for civil commitment that this Court has approved in and since the Addington case. Those two requirements, as you know, are mental illness and dangerousness. The volitional impairment that the Kansas Supreme Court has ruled was constitutionally required for civil commitment ignores the fact that psychological disorders, such as antisocial personality, can impair an individual in behavior, cognitive, perceptual, emotional, and even intellectual capacities. This Court has never indicated that there's anything constitutionally significant about a volitional impairment.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: There was a good deal of reference in our Hendricks opinion to the -- to the apparent fact that the person there had what was volitionally impaired. You're saying that was descriptive rather than essential to the holding?

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: I'm saying it was descriptive. Mr. Hendricks had apparently, and according to himself only, an inability to control his own behavior. So, when the majority wrote about Mr. Hendricks, they used that kind of a description.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Well, but we also relied on prior authority that made some reference to lack of control. I don't think that what was done by the court below was totally off the wall in light of what was said in our prior cases. What if there is some element but perhaps not to that extent? How would you draw the line?

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: Well, if this Court says that there needs to be some volitional impairment displayed, we would suggest that it just be merely some impairment. To have a total impairment is something that the psychiatrists will even tell us is an impossible standard to show.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: You think that's the standard adopted in the court below that we're reviewing?

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: I do.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Total impairment?

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: I do.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Do you acknowledge that lack of ability to control one's unlawful conduct and volitional impairment are one and the same thing?

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: No, I do not.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Suppose I'm delusional and -- and I think that -- that people I see are Satan. I'm fully able to control myself and -- and do not attack people who are not Satan, but I think that some people are Satan.

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: Your Honor, that's --

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Do you call that a lack of volitional control or delusion?

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: I would consider that delusional and not a -- a lack of volitional control. And the problem with the Kansas Supreme Court's decision is that it says the only thing that we consider is volitional impairment, but there are many kinds of impairments individuals have that are the result of their mental disorder, and so the Kansas court is necessarily limiting the psychiatric diagnosis to say only volitional impairment --

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: What is there -- I thought there could be cognitive impairments. I think Justice Scalia has described one. There could be emotional impairments.

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: Yes, sir.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: And there could be volitional impairments. Now, is there any other category?

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: Perceptual, intellectual. There -- there are many kinds that are talked about within the psychiatric material.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: But are these --

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Is there any kind relevant here other than volition?

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: Yes. I think they all are, all of those that we mentioned, and perhaps even those --

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Are relevant in this case?

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: Not -- yes.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: I'm saying is there any one relevant to the particular individual at issue here other than volition.

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: I don't believe psychiatrists can tell us what it is that -- what kind of impairment Mr. Crane has. They're not -- the -- the literature will say that psychiatrists can't tell whether or not Justice Scalia was acting because he's hallucinating or because it's some other volitional impairment, if it's an irresistible impulse, if you will, whether it's emotional, perceptual, intellectual. They can't tell. They can't get in somebody's mind. And what they have to do then is simply rely on what the individual says. Mr. Crane told this -- the court below -- he told the experts below, rather. He didn't testify. He told the experts below that he could control his behavior. Mr. Hendricks had testimony that you refer to in the Hendricks decision that said he couldn't control his behavior. So, because the psychiatrist can't make a determination objectively, we're left with a potential predator telling us who applies -- who's eligible for this law and who isn't. The other point I would make to this Court is that Mr. Hendricks said I can't control my urge to molest children. But he could. He never molested little children in front of their parents, never in front of his wife, never in front of law enforcement --

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Well, but that's not the premise that Hendricks proceeded upon. Now you're -- now you're saying that Hendricks rested on an insecure factual assumption.

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: I'm sorry, Your Honor. I don't understand.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Well, you're -- are you trying to say that what we said in Hendricks was -- was dictum or --

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: -- just was -- was wrong in the -- in the context of that case?

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: I'm certainly not saying you were wrong, Your Honor. I'm saying that you did not create a third constitutional standard, that the impairments that I --

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Well, was the Court under some misimpression as -- as to Hendricks' ability to control himself?

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: There wasn't evidence before this Court that would say whether or not Hendricks suffered from a volitional impairment or not. All we have is what he himself said.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: But then, it seems to me, that we're back to square one. I -- one reading of Hendricks -- and tell me if this is wrong -- is that we want to find some measure of determining how dangerous this person is to society because that's in the statute. And because many criminals are -- have personality disorders and are dangerous to society, we want to narrow it somewhat. So, we -- so the Court added this volitional control aspect. Is that a fair reading of Hendricks?

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: Your Honor, I don't believe it is because Mr. Hendricks, in particular, didn't suffer from a personality disorder. He had what is classified under the Kansas statute as an abnormality mentally and that was being pedophilia. The Kansas statute specifically says there are two kinds of impairment that we could look at. They're emotional as well as volitional.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Well, is the test -- are there different requirements if you proceed based on a personality disorder than if you proceed from a mental abnormality?

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: Well, the Kansas court seems to think there is because there is no definition in the statute of a personality disorder. It wasn't defined --

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Well, I was -- I was suggesting that you thought there was based on the answer you gave to me.

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: No, Your Honor. What --

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: You think they're both one and the same. You have no different requirements for mental abnormality or personality disorder. In -- in either case, the test for civil commitment is the same.

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: Based on the Kansas Supreme Court decision or based on the --

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Based on what you think the law ought to be and what the -- and how the statute is properly interpreted.

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: We believe there is no distinction. There should be no distinction between mental abnormality and personality disorder, that as long as we -- we show that mental condition and the dangerousness, that there should not be a distinction.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: So, anybody with a personality disorder that's a danger to himself or others can be -- can be civilly committed regardless of volitional control. That's -- that's your position.

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: Right. They have to have some sort of impairment in order to have the diagnosis of a personality disorder. That's part and parcel of a diagnosis of the DSM. But it would be our position it's not limited to volitional control, but could be that laundry list of emotional capacity -- emotional impairment, which is even what the Kansas statute contemplates for mental --

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: -- the DSM that you're mentioning, if you look at the definition of personality disorder and they say pick three out of a list of seven, you could pick out habitually doesn't work, doesn't pay debts, is reckless, irritable. That's something -- I mean, it's considerably less than what is defined as an abnormality like pedophilia. There are a lot of ordinary people who would fit that description.

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: What -- what I want to be able to do today, Your Honors, is to convince you that actually that's not true, that an antisocial personality disorder is a severe mental pathology that really does give us sociopaths and psychopaths that cannot conform to our rules. There are a lot of individuals in this country and certainly in our prisons that break the law, and they may suffer from antisocial personality traits, but that's entirely separate and distinct from having a full-blown diagnosis of an antisocial personality disorder.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Well, your statute itself, when you're talking about a sexually violent predator, you say mental abnormality or personality disorder, which makes the person likely to engage in repeat acts of sexual violence. So, that certainly qualifies the personality disorder. It's not any personality disorder that would do that.

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: That's exactly right, Your Honor. The point is that it's a severe diagnosis, for one thing, and then secondly, it has to tie directly to the kind of dangerous behavior that we believe these individuals will commit if they don't have the treatment.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: And I take it what your -- what your statute is trying to get at is -- is something more than mere repetitive conduct, mere recidivism. Is that fair to say?

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: Absolutely.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: And -- and is the element that distinguishes this kind of behavior from mere repetitiveness some element of lack of control, not necessarily volitional control, but some element of lack of control, perhaps lack of control resulting from delusion, perceptual difficulties and so on, but -- but some -- some aspect of the personality that -- that gives that individual a -- a lesser chance of controlling behavior in -- in a way that avoids committing crimes. Is that fair to say?

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: With a slight exception. It's the dangerousness, the risk of recidivism tied to a mental disorder. To get the diagnosis of a mental disorder, there will be an impairment that's part and parcel of that.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Right.

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: But I want to be clear that we don't think there needs to be a -- a third separate, very distinguishable constitutional element --

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: I guess what I'm -- I guess what I'm getting at is it -- it seems sensible to call somebody who is just an habitual offender at some dangerous crime or serious crime dangerous. And I take it that what the Kansas statute and other statutes like it is trying to get at, by speaking of mental disorder or personality disorder, is some extra element beyond the mere probability of doing an act which society has called dangerous. And I think -- I think --

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: That's 100 percent accurate. That's exactly where we are, Your Honor. And we think that having that mental abnormality or mental disorder gets us away from just predicting who's going to be dangerous.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: But what is that -- what is that? That's exactly the issue. What is it that you -- how -- what form of words will you use to define what counts as a mental disorder that will distinguish the people whom you want to civilly commit from your mine-run recidivist criminal?

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: That they have to have a mental --

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Yes, but what -- that's the problem in the case. The problem is what counts as a mental disorder. And the Kansas court thought what counts as a mental disorder is a total inability to control behavior.

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: That's correct.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: You say that's not the right definition. Very well. What is?

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: What is in the statute, a severe mental --

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: No, no. What is the definition of the word, mental disorder, that appears in the statute? If a person were to say every person who commits a crime, 15 times running, is a sociopath and thereby falls within DSM-IV, you're not going to permit that. You want to distinguish that sociopath from a person who is really mentally disordered and he isn't your mine-run criminal. All right. Give me the form of words that will do it.

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: I believe they are there now, that --

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: All that's there now is mental disorder.

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: Well, actually it's mental abnormality and personality disorder. You and this Court in the Hendricks decision said that pedophilia certainly qualifies as a --

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Well, and here we have -- we have here an antisocial personality disorder. That -- that was the diagnosis.

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: That's right. Along with exhibitionism.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: And the State's own expert said in Mr. Crane's trial that approximately 75 percent of the prison population has antisocial personality disorder. Now, this is an unusual statute where after the person serves a sentence for the crime, the State can then proceed again and get them locked up for a very long time because of his dangerousness.

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: And the mental disorder.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: We're trying -- okay. But most of them -- 75 percent of them was the testimony -- suffer from antisocial personality disorder. So, is the State going to be able to proceed again against 75 percent of the prison population? What is the added element beyond an antisocial personality disorder?

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: I would suggest to you that there doesn't need to be an additional element. While I acknowledge the expert said 75 percent suffers from that in the deposition, he wasn't -- he certainly didn't quote empirical studies to demonstrate that. I would suggest that probably 90-95 percent of the prison population suffer from antisocial personality traits, but that's different than a disorder. The antisocial personality disorder, psychopaths and sexual -- psychopaths and sociopaths with actual diagnosis -- and Ted Bundy is the best example of that. These are really serious individuals not 75 percent of the population.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: What is it -- what is it about them that we can isolate that shows that they are really serious beyond the mere repetition of their crime? In other words, let me put the question this way. Under -- under the rule you want us to adopt in which, as you put it, there is no third element, why aren't you free to go after, let's say, every second offender of a sexual crime at the time of release and say, this person is dangerous within -- sufficiently dangerous within the meaning of the statute to -- to commit here? Now, you're not claiming you can do that, but I want to know what it is that you have to prove that stands in the way of your being able to do that.

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: We have to show a mental illness.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: And -- and --

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: And that's a psychiatrically approved condition that --

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: No, but --

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: -- you can get an expert --

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: -- anything in the DSM.

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: Right.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Then you're --

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: I'm sorry. Not anything in the DSM.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Then you're back to Justice Ginsburg's question, which -- which is very much like Justice O'Connor's. If all you've got to do is satisfy one criterion in the DSM, you're going to pick up, in Justice O'Connor's reference to the experts, 75 percent probably of your prison population and -- and based on the -- the categorization Justice Ginsburg described, it would seem to me you would pickup a substantial part of the population outside of prison. Now, I know you don't want to do that, but on your theory that there is -- there is no third element beyond this categorization, what stands in the way of your doing that?

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: The actual diagnosis that those folks actually have those diagnosis and are sexually violent. Being sexually violent absolutely limits that. What I would --

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: All right. Are you saying then that in the example Justice Ginsburg gave you -- what was it -- four out of seven in the list?

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: Three of seven.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: That -- that as -- as long as -- as the -- the expert witness says, yes, this person is subject to four out of those seven personality traits, that that person, if a sexual offender, could be locked up under the statute?

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: They could be committed for treatment under this -- this statute, yes, Your Honor.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Wow.

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: And Mr. Crane -- what -- what I would want you to know, though, is that it is not a -- just because these individuals have committed crimes doesn't mean they have an antisocial personality disorder. Of the seven criteria that are listed, that can certainly be supplemented by independent judgment of psychiatrists, of the --

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: But it would be very -- it -- it would be -- on Justice Ginsburg's example, it would be very easy to prove.

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: It could be if they actually have that diagnosis and have those personality traits and have done that behavior. If I -- although it is not in the record, what I would like this Court to know is that out of 5,000 individuals that have been screened in this process in Kansas, a mere 1 -- less than 1 and a half percent have actually been civilly committed. And we have --

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: -- the prosecutor then, but I mean, that's not something that -- that we would generally do. I mean, if we thought of all prosecutors as being wise and kind and good, then there would be a whole lot of rights that we wouldn't have to worry about.

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: I understand.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: But Justice Kennedy brought up in -- in Hendricks a concern, and this case seems to fit that. That is, this man entered a plea bargain.

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: I'm sorry?

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: He entered a plea bargain. Right? And he got a relatively short time. And then, through this civil process, without beyond a reasonable doubt as the standard, just a preponderance --

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: No. There is a reasonable -- beyond a reasonable doubt, yes.

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: It is beyond a --

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: But it is a civil proceeding.

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: It is but we have that higher standard.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: May I --

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Still, you could -- you could get to where you were or even beyond. You could get to the full amount of time that the person could have been sentenced if there had been no plea bargain, and if you -- the maximum penalty because this is indefinite. Right?

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: It's indefinite with annual reviews, and they are allowed to be released when they have been determined safe to be at large. And while it is not part of the record, I would want you to know that Mr. Crane is in transitional release now, after about 3 years in this treatment program.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: What do the annual reviews -- what do they deal with? Is it possible at -- at the end of an annual review for the person to be released?

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: Yes. Could go to the transitional release phase and then the conditional release phase and then ultimately to final discharge. The annual release ensures -- the annual review, rather, ensures that they're not warehoused, that they have an opportunity to come to the court on an annual basis.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: What does the court have to find in order to release them? It is no longer beyond a reasonable doubt that --

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: Then it's -- the State has to show -- I'm sorry. The -- the respondent has to show probable cause that they have changed. The State, as a matter of policy, never objects when there are psychiatrists say they're safe to be in the next phase of the program or the next. We've never objected to that. We have six that are actually out of the facility now and in either transitional and/or conditional release.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: And isn't it a frequent case, though, that the psychiatrists say, well, we can't tell until we clinically re-observe him and we can't clinically observe him until he's in a normal environment? I mean, can psychiatrists --

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: It hasn't happened in the six so far that -- that have -- have been released.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: The American Psychiatric Association says in their brief that the, quote, antisocial personality disorder, end quote, which is DSM-IV at 701- 706, applies to 40 to 60 percent among the male-sentenced population. So, are you saying that 40 to 60 percent of the male-sentenced population could be committed for life civilly? Are you saying that DSM-IV is not the standard, or are you saying that the American Psychiatric Association is wrong when it tells us 40 percent to 60 percent fit within the DSM-IV definition?

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: In terms of the antisocial personality disorder alone, I don't know. What I would say is that certainly 40 to 60 percent --

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: All right.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Did they say how they know? I -- I -- you know, I could --

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: I -- I don't know if they know or not.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: If -- if they stated --

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: But I know they know better than I do.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Did they say that 40 to 60 percent are beyond a reasonable doubt suffering from an antisocial personality disorder?

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: I doubt that, and I doubt that -- that it applies to --

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: The reason -- the point of my question is, is DSM-IV the standard and if DSM-IV is not the standard, what is? That's what I think all of us, or several of us anyway, are trying to get to. And it may be you -- you cannot address that further, but if you could.

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: The DSM-IV absolutely is the standard in the psychiatric profession, but it is not the Bible and is not the only thing psychiatrists use. They very much can supplement that with their own judgment, and in fact, that's part of the prefatory language in the DSM.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: May I ask you this question? And I'm concerned about whether the instructions were adequate and whether you think the instructions were adequate. And one of the reasons I have the question is they do not seem, on their face, to require any finding of volitional impairment. And it seems to me we might look at volitional impairment in three different ways, one that has to be total inability to comply, some inability to comply, or that it's totally irrelevant to the issue. Which of those three positions is yours?

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: The last, that it's irrelevant to a diagnosis.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: There's no need to show any volitional impairment in order to obtain a commitment under this statute, so the instruction is correct.

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: That -- that is absolutely the State's position.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: And I think it's also unnecessary to show any other kind of impairment in addition to the two elements that you're describing.

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: In order to get a -- in terms of the instructions, that's true because to get a diagnosis, you have to have an impairment. You can't be diagnosed with anything under DSM without having an impairment. So, it's part and parcel.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: -- the actual difficulty in controlling, not -- not utter inability to control conduct, but difficulty in controlling conduct. Don't you have to show that?

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: She said -- she didn't say that.

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: I don't believe we have to show that.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: How could the person be dangerous --

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: Because they have this --

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: -- by reason of the personality disorder if the personality disorder does not produce a difficulty in -- in controlling conduct?

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: In order to link together the --

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: I must say, I thought -- I thought you conceded that you have to show difficulty in controlling conduct, and if you don't, this is a quite different case from what I thought.

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: And I misspoke, Your Honor. The -- within the definition of the mental abnormality itself, we don't have to show lack of control, but the statutory language then leads us into that you have this mental abnormality or disorder that makes you likely or that predisposes you. So, there is the connection that we have to show.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Well, no --

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: In other words --

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: It predisposes you to do things you want to do.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Yes.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: So that, it seems to me, doesn't answer the question.

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: Our --

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Where is it in the statutory language that talks about volitional control? It doesn't.

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: The mental abnormality is defined in the statute and it does mention both volitional and emotional capacity --

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: A personality disorder does not.

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: It is not defined and I think that's because it's such a common term, the legislature didn't define it. Mental abnormality was a very unique term. So, I think they chose to define it, but they include emotional as well as volitional impairments there. And if the Kansas Supreme Court is right, then you must strike out emotional because we could prove it under the statute by an emotional impairment that they say is not valid. Only a volitional impairment is allowed. And -- and so --

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: But you say emotional is, and -- and I guess emotional impairment I suppose would describe every sociopath in the country. I mean, I thought a sociopath by definition was somebody who just didn't care about society's standards.

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: That is absolutely one part --

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: That would satisfy as an emotional impairment, wouldn't it?

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: It is an emotional impairment, yes, Your Honor. That's true.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: So --

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: But the Kansas court would say that --

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: -- in fact, we -- I think we get back to the point that on your theory any sociopath who has committed a -- a sexual offense can be committed under this statute upon release.

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: But it takes more than having the likelihood of committing more sex crimes and/or not having any empathy before you could be diagnosed with an antisocial personality disorder. And so, there --

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: It would take -- it would take four out of seven on Justice Ginsburg's list.

completeLines.speaker: STOVALL
completeLines.speech: It takes three, actually three of seven. But it does make a significant diagnosis. It is a mental pathology. It isn't something that --

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: Beyond a reasonable doubt.

completeLines.speech: So, they can't do it with control because control has to do with volition.

completeLines.speaker: DONHAM
completeLines.speech: This would be a person susceptible to commitment because he's unable to care for himself, and therefore poses a danger.

completeLines.speaker: QUESTION
completeLines.speech: No. He cares for himself perfectly. He just has this emotional impairment. What do we do? It's a problem.

completeLines.speaker: DONHAM
completeLines.speech: Yes, it is. It's a significant problem because were talking about depriving people of their liberty, and we're -- we're basing it on the testimony of people who don't fully understand their field of expertise at times, which is why this Court should set a high benchmark to preclude the inadvertent commitment of someone who really shouldn't have gone to a mental hospital. I'm particularly distressed over the use of an antisocial personality disorder in that it is -- it is given simply to someone who has a history of offenses. So, that history of offenses provides the basis for the diagnosis, and it provides the basis for the prediction of future dangerousness. In effect, the State seeks to involuntarily commit someone because they have a long prior criminal history. My time is almost up. If there are no more questions.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE REHNQUIST
completeLines.speech: Thank you, Mr. Donham. The case is submitted.
